Award.AwardTitle: Developing Diagnostics for Vibrio Coralliilyticus and Coral Vibriosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will catalyze new collaborative research on pathogenic marine vibrios between Dr. Claudia Hase at Oregon State University, Corvallis, Oregon, and Dr. David Bourne of the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) in Townsville, Australia. The long-term goal of this collaboration is a better understanding of the role and ecology of Vibrio bacteria associated with coral disease. The research objectives of this visit are to examine the feasibility of methods developed by Dr. Hase to detect certain enzymes from Vibrio coralliilyticus. V. tubiashii has recently caused devastating losses in shellfish larvae production in the Pacific Northwest of the US and Dr. Hase has shown that a secreted metalloprotease is a critical factor for the toxicity of V. tubiashii. Dr. Bourne reported that a 99% similar enzyme of V. coralliilyticus is critical for coral bleaching and outlined the urgent need for better diagnostic tools for coral disease. Rapid and specific detection of pathogenic bacteria and their toxins in natural waters and diseased corals is paramount to better understand disease causation and to provide early warning allowing reef managers to mitigate the effect of disease outbreaks. Thus, this collaboration will benefit a broad range of marine research activities.

The broader impacts of this proposed work include providing support for an OSU student to travel with the PI to AIMS and current students in the Bourne lab will participate in the proposed work. The described project provides excellent educational opportunities for students as most of the proposed experiments are straightforward and are well suited for the engagement of students in the scientific process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coral disease incidence has dramatically increased in recent decades, and is a major cause of the decline of tropical reefs.  Although several studies have attempted to identify the causative agents of coral diseases, only few have convincingly pinpointed a particular bacterium as the etiological agent of a given disease, highlighting the urgent need for better diagnostic tools for coral infectious diseases.  Several reports since have identified Vibrio spp. as common coral pathogens, including the bacterium Vibrio coralliilyticus.  Interestingly, virulence of V. coralliilyticus is temperature sensitive, in that only under conditions of elevated temperatures the organism produces the toxins associated with infection.  During our study of the recent reemergence of vibriosis in shellfish hatcheries in the Pacific Northwest, we developed an on-site, real-time sensitive diagnostic method for the early detection of vibriosis commercial shellfish production facilities. This new test consists of a “simple” dipstick, similar to a pregnancy test with detection and control lines, is well suited as a potential diagnostic tool for coral Vibrio infection detection as the same organism, V. coralliilyticus, was found to utilize a zinc-metalloprotease (the antigen detected by the dipsticks) for both shellfish as well as coral disease. Thus, during our NSF-funded collaboration between Dr. Häse (at Oregon State University) and Dr. Bourne (at Australian Institute for Marine Science, Australia) we were able to assess the capability of the dipstick detection assay to function in the context of coral infectious diseases.  The AIMS institute is uniquely situated in the world, being in close proximity to the Great Barrier Reef.  This project filled a critical gap in coral research that has previously been identified in terms of developing novel diagnostic technologies in the marine field.
